Award.AbstractNarration:
The basic question of the investigation is to determine which expansions of semialgebraic geometry can (or should) be considered as tame and can be handled by model theoretic techniques. One of the central goals of this investigation is to achieve a better understanding of the geometric consequences of the non-definability of the set of integers on the definability of fractals. Towards this goal, we will apply methods from real analysis, geometric measure theory and model theory, some of which have not yet been used in the study of expansions of the real field. The insights of this research are not only important in the fundamental study of tameness in ordered fields, but should also prove useful to questions in control theory and real-analytic geometry.

The study of o-minimal geometry, a branch of mathematical logic, can be considered as a framework for studying tame geometric objects. In the last two decades researchers proved that many classical phenomena from real-analytic geometry fall into the framework of o-minimality. This has led to advances not only in geometry, but also in other branches of mathematics like Lie theory and number theory, and in such diverse fields as general equilibrium theory in economics and neural networks in computer science. Unfortunately, o-minimality can only be used to model phenomena that are at least locally finite (more precisely, locally having only finitely many connected components). Many natural geometric objects like spirals or fractals do not have this finiteness property and hence the known techniques are unapplicable to such an object. Hieronymi aims to overcome this limitation by studying tameness even outside the setting of local finiteness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At the heart of logic and model theory lays the observation that within mathematics there are certain objects that have to be considered tame, and others that have to be considered wild. Many celebrated results in logic from the first half of the 20th century, like Gödel’s incompleteness theorem, concerned the existence of objects that are wild from a logical viewpoint, while in the second half of the last century model theorists found a vast number of mathematical structures that exhibit no such wildness, and for often very different reasons can be thought of as being tame. This program of identifying and analyzing tame classes of structures whose model theory can be understood came to be known as the geography of tame mathematics and in its various forms has dominated model theory throughout the last thirty years. Although arising as a program of foundational importance, it has led to striking applications of model theory to other areas of mathematics, most recently in Pila’s work on the Andre-Oort conjecture.

During the funding period of this grant, the PI made significant contributions to this research area. Most prominently the PI showed that an expansion of the real field can only be tame if on all closed definable sets all commonly-encountered metric dimensions coincide. This gives a striking restriction on what kind structures fall into framework of tame geometry. Moreover, the PI gave an answer to a long-standing open question about when scalar multiplication is decidable (in a certain model-theoretic setting). Further he answered a question of Friedman-Kurdyka-Miller-Speissegger on the complexity of definable sets in expansions of the real field by Cantor sets.

 As part of the broader impact of this grant, the PI organized a large outreach called "Gathering for Gardner at Urbana-Champaign" in October 2014. At the occasion of Martin Gardner’s 100th birthday the Department of Mathematics at Illinois hosted a celebration of recreational mathematics and fun math puzzles. The event celebrated Gardner not by hosting talks about his impact, but rather by sharing his and the participants’ enthusiasm for mathematics with the next generation. At this math fair children of all ages were able to attempt and solve a large variety of Gardner’s puzzles. Local mathematicians and computer scientists (students and faculty) provided demonstrations of magic tricks and visual paradoxes gave the children puzzles and helped them solve the harder ones. Overall, around 200 members of the Urbana-Champaign community attended this event, most of them middle school and elementary school students with their parents.
